725275f-a.title: Queens: 38th Avenue - Main Street
725275f-a.text:
THirty-eimhth Avenue, south side, (old No. 139-141)
between Main and Union Streets, showing a view of a colored
school which was erected in 1819. In 1926 it housed the
African Nethodist piscopal Church.
1922
Eueene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

727318f-a.title: Queens: Main Street - 38th Avenue
727318f-a.text:
Main Street, north of the N.W. corner of Thirty-eighth Ave. (left),
showing at the corner the D. Master's House of 1873. In 1874 Miss
S.0. Hoffman's school for girls was conducted in this house. It had
only day students. In 1876 a limited number of boarders were here.
Mrs. Master succeeded Miss Hoffman. Dr. Hans Schuler purchased the school
in 1888 and organized the Flushing Female Seminary. In 1926 the building
stands but is no lOnger used as a seminary. It has had the boards re-
moved and has been finished with stucco.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

727335f-a.title: Queens: Main Street - 38th Avenue
727335f-a.text:
Main Street, west side, between 39th and 38th Avenuea,
showing St. Georges Protestant Episcopal Church. The view is
north.
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS  April 13, 1927

725276f-a.title: Queens: 38th Avenue - Main Street
725276f-a.text:
Thirty-eighth Avenue (old No. 108-110 Lincoln Street) north
side, between Main and Union Streets, showing the Craig house.
In 1873 either C.W. Howard, P. Cleary, or G. Higbie was the
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

725277f-a.title: Queens: 38th Avenue - Main Street
725277f-a.text:
Thirty-eighth Avenue (rear of 128 Lincoln Avenue), north
side, between Main and Union Streets, showing a rear view of
an old home ante dating 1873.
January 1923.
Eumene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

725278f-a.title: Queens: 38th Avenue - Main Street
725278f-a.text:
108-110 Thirty-eighth Ave. (Lincoln Ave.), north side, east of
Main Street, showing the raig howae.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

727317f-b.title: Queens: Main Street - 38th Avenue
727317f-b.text:
Main St., west side, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Aves.,
showing in a set of 4 views the St. George's Frotestant Episcopal
Church and the Peck and Bloodgood Cemetery. The first services of
this Congregation were held in the blockhouse, which in 1704 was
called the Guardhouse. It stood on a site on which the Orthodox
Quaker's meeting house was erected in 1827. This site is now
occupied by the new armory (east of the Hicksite Quaker's meeting
house of 1694-5). The first church edifice was erected near Main St.,
facing on Thirty-eighth Ave., in 1743-46, and was completed in 1761.
It stood on a one-half acre tract donated by Captain Ralph Wentworth
in 1745. The second edifice seen partially in views 3 and 4 was
erected in 1812 and consecrated either on May 25 or June 25, 1821
by Bishop Hobart and enlarged in 1838 or 4O at a cost of 1700.
Twenty-six pews were added. It was removed to its present site
facing Thirty-eighth Ave. in 1853 and repaired in 1858. It was
demolished in 1920. The third edifice was erected between 1853
and 54 at a cost of 33,000 and later enlarged and the interior
remodeled. The cornerstone was laid on May 18th or 24th 1853 and
the building consecrated on June 1, 1854. Rev. J. Carpenter Smith
was the rector from Nov. 1847 to 1896. The charter of this
congregation dates from 1760.
1922
Views 1,3 and 4.
View 21 March 1924.
